headline: Stock Futures Rebound Following Brutal Tech Selloff
summary: Stocks looked set to edge higher on Monday, clawing back some of their recent losses as investors bought the dip ahead of a slew of economic data and some crucial central bank policy decisions.  “The weakest AI stories are increasingly being punished rather than the pre-September period when AI all went up together,” Deutsche Bank analyst Jim Reid said on Monday.  Shutdown-delayed employment reports for October and November due out Tuesday will give investors a better sense of how the labor market is faring, which could be key to determining if the Federal Reserve carries on cutting interest rates next year.

content.title: Stock Futures Rebound Following Brutal Tech Selloff
content.summary: Stocks looked set to edge higher on Monday, clawing back some of their recent losses as investors bought the dip ahead of a slew of economic data and some crucial central bank policy decisions.  “The weakest AI stories are increasingly being punished rather than the pre-September period when AI all went up together,” Deutsche Bank analyst Jim Reid said on Monday.  Shutdown-delayed employment reports for October and November due out Tuesday will give investors a better sense of how the labor market is faring, which could be key to determining if the Federal Reserve carries on cutting interest rates next year.

headline: Chinese Tech Stocks Stumble Amid Sluggish Sentiment
summary: Chinese chip and tech stocks stumbled as the negative sentiment on Wall Street carried over into Monday's session. "Hong Kong tech is getting hit from both sides—Wall Street's AI hangover is dampening global appetite for growth names, and weak China data is reminding investors that the domestic demand story still isn't healing," Saxo Markets chief investment strategist Charu Chanana said in an email.

headline: Fed: Will AI be a labor productivity booster or worry in 2026?
summary: After the Federal Reserve voted to cut interest rates by 25 basis points at its December FOMC meeting on Wednesday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled a rate pause to come in 2026 as officials digest incoming economic data. Powell went on to comment on the AI-driven productivity trends in the US labor market. Ameriprise Financial Chief Economist Russell Price and Waddell and Associates CEO and Chief Investment Strategist David Waddell expand upon where AI may boost labor productivity and where indicators of an AI bubble — such as around Oracle (ORCL) — are beginning to show face. Also catch Russell Price and David Waddell's expert perspectives on Powell's outlook on US GDP (gross domestic product). To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.

content.title: Fed: Will AI be a labor productivity booster or worry in 2026?
content.description:
After the Federal Reserve voted to cut interest rates by 25 basis points at its December FOMC meeting on Wednesday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled a rate pause to come in 2026 as officials digest incoming economic data. Powell went on to comment on the AI-driven productivity trends in the US labor market.

Ameriprise Financial Chief Economist Russell Price and Waddell and Associates CEO and Chief Investment Strategist David Waddell expand upon where AI may boost labor productivity and where indicators of an AI bubble — such as around Oracle (ORCL) — are beginning to show face.

Also catch Russell Price and David Waddell's expert perspectives on Powell's outlook on US GDP (gross domestic product).

To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination.
content.summary: After the Federal Reserve voted to cut interest rates by 25 basis points at its December FOMC meeting on Wednesday, Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled a rate pause to come in 2026 as officials digest incoming economic data. Powell went on to comment on the AI-driven productivity trends in the US labor market. Ameriprise Financial Chief Economist Russell Price and Waddell and Associates CEO and Chief Investment Strategist David Waddell expand upon where AI may boost labor productivity and where indicators of an AI bubble — such as around Oracle (ORCL) — are beginning to show face. Also catch Russell Price and David Waddell's expert perspectives on Powell's outlook on US GDP (gross domestic product). headline: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

content.title: Wall Street Has Lots of Questions. Stock Markets Might Not Like the Answers They Get This Week.
content.summary: Wall Street could find answers to some of its most important questions over the next five days as the final full trading week of a difficult year looks set to provide key tests to narratives about the economy, artificial- intelligence stocks, and the path of the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy.  Investors enter the week, which typically marks the start of a traditional late-December rally, in a cautiously optimistic mood, with market volatility gauges ticking higher and benchmark  Treasury bond  yields trading north of levels seen prior to last week’s interest-rate cut by the U.S. central bank.  Megacap tech stocks also are on the back foot, with declines this month for every member of the so-called Magnificent 7 cohort apart from  Tesla  and big late-week declines for  Oracle  and  Broadcom  following mixed quarterly earnings updates that added to concerns over near-term profitability.

headline: Bridgewater warns Big Tech's reliance on external capital to fund AI boom is 'dangerous'
summary: The AI spending boom is entering a "dangerous" phase as Big Tech firms increasingly tap external ​investors to cover mounting costs, a top executive ‌at hedge fund giant Bridgewater Associates said on Monday.  The warning underscores the degree ‌of unease rippling through markets as several investors have begun to question the sustainability of massive capital spending on AI.  While the technology has deeply permeated the economy, critics are beginning to ⁠wonder how severe ‌the fallout could be if the boom fails to translate into tangible profits.

content.title: Bridgewater warns Big Tech's reliance on external capital to fund AI boom is 'dangerous'
content.summary: The AI spending boom is entering a "dangerous" phase as Big Tech firms increasingly tap external ​investors to cover mounting costs, a top executive ‌at hedge fund giant Bridgewater Associates said on Monday.  The warning underscores the degree ‌of unease rippling through markets as several investors have begun to question the sustainability of massive capital spending on AI.  While the technology has deeply permeated the economy, critics are beginning to ⁠wonder how severe ‌the fallout could be if the boom fails to translate into tangible profits.

headline: Oracle Is Getting Hammered Over AI Spending. It’s Time for a Second Look.
summary: Oracle  stock fell to its lowest levels since early June, extending its late autumn slump, as investors continue to question the huge amounts of debt the cloud-computing company is taking on to fund its new artificial- intelligence strategy.  Oracle told investors last week that it plans to spend around $50 billion during the current fiscal year, which ends May 31, on its AI data-center projects.  Co-CEO Clay Magouyrk further rattled investors’ nerves, declining to put a figure on the amount of money Oracle would need to cover the gap between what it can pay via its own revenue and what it plans to spend on AI.

content.title: Oracle Is Getting Hammered Over AI Spending. It’s Time for a Second Look.
content.summary: Oracle  stock fell to its lowest levels since early June, extending its late autumn slump, as investors continue to question the huge amounts of debt the cloud-computing company is taking on to fund its new artificial- intelligence strategy.  Oracle told investors last week that it plans to spend around $50 billion during the current fiscal year, which ends May 31, on its AI data-center projects.  Co-CEO Clay Magouyrk further rattled investors’ nerves, declining to put a figure on the amount of money Oracle would need to cover the gap between what it can pay via its own revenue and what it plans to spend on AI.

headline: Oracle a ‘Show Me Story’ on Big AI Debt Bet, JPMorgan Says
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. credit analyst Erica Spear expects pressures on the company’s bonds will persist in the new year.  Oracle’s stock plunged the most in almost 11 months and a measure of the firm’s credit risk reached a fresh 16-year high last week.

content.title: Oracle a ‘Show Me Story’ on Big AI Debt Bet, JPMorgan Says
content.summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co. credit analyst Erica Spear expects pressures on the company’s bonds will persist in the new year.  Oracle’s stock plunged the most in almost 11 months and a measure of the firm’s credit risk reached a fresh 16-year high last week.

headline: US stocks drift ahead of Tuesday's jobs report
summary: Wall Street drifted through a quiet day of trading on Monday, ahead of economic reports this week that could drive where interest rates go.  The S&P 500 slipped 0.2%, though the majority of stocks within the index rose.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 41 points, or 0.1%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.6%.

content.title: US stocks drift ahead of Tuesday's jobs report
content.summary: Wall Street drifted through a quiet day of trading on Monday, ahead of economic reports this week that could drive where interest rates go.  The S&P 500 slipped 0.2%, though the majority of stocks within the index rose.  The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 41 points, or 0.1%, and the Nasdaq composite fell 0.6%.

thumbnail.caption: Specialists Alex Weitzman, left, and Meric Greenbaum work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Thursday, Dec. 11, 2025. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

content.title: Microsoft's AI advantage isn't all about OpenAI — and Wall Street loves it
content.summary: Investors say Microsoft's real edge comes from its sprawling AI ecosystem and growing independence from any single model provider.

headline: Why OpenAI dominated the AI trade in 2025
summary: Opening Bid Unfiltered is available on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, YouTube, or wherever you get your podcasts. There has been one company at the very center of the AI trade this year. That is none other than OpenAI (OPAI.PVT)! OpenAI has won Yahoo Finance’s 11th annual Company of the Year award. Here is why. First, it undeniably led the market narrative for investors in 2025. When it announced big deals, stocks popped. When it issued a cautionary statement, stocks took a hit. Second, OpenAI secured scores of new, transformational deals with large public companies, including Nvidia (NVDA), AMD (AMD), and Oracle (ORCL). And three, its year of dealmaking will likely see the company end the year as the world’s most valuable private business — with an estimated valuation of $500 billion, according to Yahoo Finance data. Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi talked exclusively with OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar about the company’s path forward — from eventually turning profitable to a potential push into hardware. Listen on your favorite podcast platform or watch on our website for full episodes of Opening Bid Unfiltered. Yahoo Finance's Opening Bid Unfiltered is produced by Langston Sessoms.

Yahoo Finance Executive Editor Brian Sozzi talked exclusively with OpenAI CFO Sarah Friar about the company’s path forward — from eventually turning profitable to a potential push into hardware.

Listen on your favorite podcast platform or watch on our website for full episodes of Opening Bid Unfiltered.

Yahoo Finance's Opening Bid Unfiltered is produced by Langston Sessoms.

headline: Heard on the Street Recap: AI Burnout Builds
summary: What Happened in Markets Today Stocks down on more AI fatigue. Weakness across major tech stocks weighed down the S&P 500 and Nasdaq on Monday. The Dow was up slightly in the afternoon but ended up closing down a slight 41 points.
